\t\tAs the tides receded, the villagers emerged from their fallen homes, eyes sweeping over the destruction, minds comprehending, but rejecting what it meant. Splintered wood and battered furniture floated amidst the few fortuitous structures that weathered the storm – they are all that is left of the once beautiful floating city, Kaliku.\n
\t\tCries of sorrow, like raindrops falling on a silent lake, shattered the crimson sunset, as the weight of loss finally overcame the survivors. The tidal wave had taken everything including any hope. Once glimmering eyes, full of joy and hope, are now shot with blood, pain and tears.\n
\t\tIt was all over. There wasn\'t anything that could bring back the life and happiness destroyed in that instant. The cries of newly orphaned children and villages hugging their love ones\' motionless and cold body were only sounds of life that could be heard.

\t\tGently, the travelling priestess came forward, and told the survivors to gather the fallen. Despite her strength, her training, despite her magic, she failed to stop the tidal wave, failed to stop the cause of it. The powerlessness, guilt, and remorse burned in her like scalding acid. She could not save them, but she would do all she could to send them on their way to the afterlife.\n
\t\tAnd so, once the bodies were gathered, she danced, danced like she never had, like only she knew how. The Dance of Passing. Staff in hand, she swayed in the failing sunlight, left and right, back and forth, summoning that hidden strength so few were gifted with. Her shadow faltered as she jumped and swirled, as the sun finally fell over the horizon…\n
\t\tBut was then slowly re-established by small orbs of light materialising from the bodies of the dead – Pyres, the souls of the fallen. And they danced with her, each glowing brighter and brighter with each gesture, purified by her magic. And finally, as the priestess completed her tribute, slowly to a gentle bow, the lights softened to a warm glow, and vanished into the darkness of the night.
